bioghist.p: Benjamin Jones (1767-1849), born in Pennsylvania, was the son of Joseph Jones (b. 1739) and Hannah Walter, and grandson of Rees Jones and Amy Cock. Benjamin Jones became a merchant, iron manufacturer, and land speculator. He married Rebecca Moore (b. 1778), and together they had William Jones (1798-1798), Walter Moore Jones (1799-1825), and Andrew Moore Jones (1801-1885). After Rebecca's early death in 1802, Benjamin married Mary Howell (1778-1836), and they had eight children: Anne Emlen (1806-1883), William Howell (1808-1819), Margaretta Howell (1809-1874), Richard (1812-1890), Mary Beveridge (1814-1887), Harriet (1816-1855), Samuel Howell (1818-1883), and Benjamin Walter (1821-1883). Following Benjamin Jones's death in 1849, the responsibilities of his estate fell to his son Andrew. In 1840 Andrew married Caroline Bonsall. The couple had no children. Margaretta Howell Jones (1809-1874), daughter of Benjamin, married John Madison Taylor and settled in Maryland. Their daughter Carrie Taylor was married to James Maynard who was marshal to the consular courts in Turkey. Other family members went on to fight in the Civil War, and still others fought in World War I. Although the Joneses were successful merchants, Benjamin and Andrew, with some help from younger son Richard (1812-1890), appear to be the only two that ran the family business. Later members of the family went into different fields of work.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Andrew M. Jones and other members of the Jones and Taylor families. Family correspondence in the collection includes letters to Andrew M. Jones and Caroline B. Jones from family members, including Samuel H. Jones, Richard Jones, Harriet Jones, Anne Emlen, Benjamin Jones Jr., Carrie Taylor (later Carrie Maynard), James Maynard, and J. M. Taylor. Letters discuss activities of family and friends and matters related to the estates of Benjamin Jones Sr. and M. J. Taylor. Business correspondence largely relates to land purchases and sales, with some letters relating to the iron business. The collection also includes; several receipts; bills for tuition; miscellaneous pamphlets; newspaper clippings of recipes, shipping news, and poetry; a list of chateaux in France; a survey of a plot of land in St. Mary's County, Maryland, drawn for Thomas W. Gough; and a printed description of lands owned by Benjamin and A. M Jones in Elk and M'Kean Counties, Pennsylvania.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
